I'll keep testing the issue for some time and report back if it still persists.

events.target_title: reduce noise during a crash

note.body:
So in theory I support this, but in practice I have a concern. We have several hundred dupes of this F27 bug report:

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1510059

any time gnome-shell crashes on this path in F27 and the user submits a report, it gets marked as a dupe of that bug, basically. So, that's clearly happened hundreds of times. However, we only ever have had 132 abrt-submitted crash reports for XWayland, for *any* Fedora release, if my search-fu is correct:

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/buglist.cgi?bug_status=NEW&bug_status=ASSIGNED&bug_status=POST&bug_status=MODIFIED&bug_status=ON_DEV&bug_status=ON_QA&bug_status=VERIFIED&bug_status=RELEASE_PENDING&bug_status=CLOSED&classification=Fedora&component=xorg-x11-server&f1=status_whiteboard&f2=short_desc&list_id=8670474&o1=substring&o2=substring&product=Fedora&query_format=advanced&v1=abrt_hash&v2=Xwayland

That seems quite low, and makes me wonder if there's an issue with reporting of XWayland crashes, or if it's only that people commonly choose to report the Shell crash rather than the XWayland crash for some reason?

This from @tobiasmue 
>  So I want to make a security related thing.  The biggest challenge now
is to come up with a few items and invite people to join.

>  I'm thinking of

> * Assess Internet communication security
    Where do our apps communicate with the Internet and what can a
    passive adversary learn from that.  Aka: Do we do proper TLS?  With
    validation of the certificate?  And the content that is coming from
    the API?  I imagine us to experiment with a freshly installed GNOME
    system and passively monitor the traffic it generates.


> * Protection against rogue USB devices
    Currently you can plug in a USB device at any time and your system
    will happily load any driver associated with that device.  Also when
    you've locked the screen and are thus not in front of your machine.
    We have the technology bits ready, but need to integrate that now
    into a nice GNOME experience.  For example, what do we do with
    devices that have multiple interfaces like the BadUSB keyboard and
    CD-ROM drive?  Do we block those keyboards?  How do we treat
    keyboards anyway? Do we lock the screen? But that breaks e.g.
    yubikeys for entering passwords.
>* Secure Apps
    It is now very easy to build GNOME applications through buildstream
    or flatpak manifest.  We can leverage that for building apps to
    assess their security with regards to memory management by compiling
    apps with technologies like ASan.  This, however, is not wildly used
    although it is known to find exploitable flaws in programs. Let's
    think about how we can provide developers and users with such builds
    for finding and fixing critical bugs in our software.

and this is my idea
> Since it is in Asia area, I am suggesting BOFs also about how to make people want to do more contribution because GNOME have big number of user here.

events.target_title: Warn about potential homograph attacks

note.body: ascii also containes confusables, e.g. l1 an rnm(exactly how confusable they are depends on the font and kerning)

events.target_title: Warn about potential homograph attacks

note.body: Regarding point 2, the Matrix spec says that https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3986#section-3.2.2 applies, so hostnames should only contain ascii characters. However, this seems like it is easy to get wrong on the server side, so at the very least Fractal should (if it does not do so already) convert any UTF-8 hostenames to the correct ASCII format. This is, however, easier said than done, since lots of API endpoints return hostnames in various fields, and you'd have to make sure you catch them all.

```

[753412.407]  -> wl_surface@6.frame(new id wl_callback@12)
[753412.417]  -> wl_surface@6.attach(wl_buffer@14, 0, 0)
[753412.449]  -> wl_surface@6.damage(0, 0, 2147483647, 2147483647)
[753412.503]  -> wl_surface@6.commit()
[753423.913] wl_display@1.delete_id(11)
[753423.945] wl_display@1.delete_id(12)
[753423.954] wl_callback@11.done(1096767734)
[753423.970] wl_buffer@9.release()
[753423.976] wl_callback@12.done(1096767734)
[753424.509]  -> wl_surface@6.frame(new id wl_callback@12)
[753424.538]  -> wl_surface@6.frame(new id wl_callback@11)
[753424.549]  -> wl_surface@6.attach(wl_buffer@9, 0, 0)
[753424.562]  -> wl_surface@6.damage(0, 0, 2147483647, 2147483647)
[753424.610]  -> wl_surface@6.commit()
[753444.826] wl_display@1.delete_id(12)
[753444.862] wl_display@1.delete_id(11)
[753444.873] wl_callback@12.done(1096767751)
[753444.911] wl_buffer@14.release()
```

events.target_title: Gnome Shell crash with places-status extension when you plug an USB device

note.body:
> My first guess: the clean `exit(1)` may mean that somewhere in that patch stack, we are returning false from a function call from JS into C, without throwing a JS exception with `gjs_throw()` or the like

Should that be an `abort()` or `g_error()` rather than `exit(1)`, so that the host process dumps core and systems like systemd-coredump, abrt, apport get a crash report?

Or if not that, I'd expect gjs to log to stderr (with `g_critical()` or `fprintf()`) before forcibly exiting the host process. On the Debian bug we don't seem to be seeing that.

events.target_title: Clicking on the lock screen crashes gnome shell

note.body:
> Looking at the logs and trying to grab a trace using gdb tells me that the process is actually returning and not crashing, so I can’t gather any useful information

If you're using gdb interactively (via ssh or something) you could put a breakpoint on the exit function:

```
(gdb) break exit
(gdb) continue
... trigger the unintended exit ...
(gdb) bt
```

Design a common Illustration style

note.body:
My only wonder about the "photo-realistic inside symbolic icons" use in is that they tie in term of shape (by using the symbolic icons), but they feel way more detailed than the rest of the visual style (and sometimes with my bad eyes I tend to take too much time to try to understand what is inside the icons, but that might just be me). It's not necessarily a problem (differences between elements are part also of what makes a visual style), but the difference is now (with the new icon style) big enough for me to remark it instantly... 

And I feel that it might also become more "different" depending on what road is taken in other illustration styles. But it might be less jarring that I fear it could become, with the existence of photo-realistic stock wallpaper and avatar.

> There are various aspects to GNOME's visuals, and I think that this issue is partly about trying to figure out how they fit together. It therefore might be useful to list what they are:

Isn't there also "blueprint-style" icons used in the sound test window ? (I didn't followed that though, so maybe I'm wrong)

events.target_title: Design a common Illustration style

note.body:
> For empty placeholders, again use large colour icons. These would be simpler than our other colour icons and would use a more muted palette. In many cases they could be a modified version of an existing icon.

I wonder if for this just using the symbolic icons with some touch of color and/or some background (like a light circle of color) wouldn't be at the same time simpler to do (as it doesn't mean creating a variation of the application icon), for a *somewhat* similar result (creating a muted icon for a "placeholder" state). I'm not sure that creating another asset for that would be worth it, tbh.

On dark application, it could be some form of grey from the palette, and on lighter application, use a touch of color corresponding of what an empty state convey in the context ? (for instnance having an empty result on a search doesn't seems to me quite the same thing as having one on a folder or on a content application and could use another color than basic placeholder ? or the placeholder color could be related to the application basic icon ?)

events.target_title: Make atk.pc require glib

note.body:
We've had to patch atk-2.34.1 like this in NixOS as we saw a bunch of packages failed finding included headers after upgrading (see eg. this [build log](https://hydra.nixos.org/build/100873509/nixlog/1)).

The atk.pc file for 3.32 looked like this (changed in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/atk/commit/b7bf5f1fad26051892b0adb23936813798292583):
```
  Name: Atk
  Description: Accessibility Toolkit
  Version: 2.32.0
  Requires: gobject-2.0
  Libs: -L${libdir} -latk-1.0
  Cflags: -I${includedir}/atk-1.0
```

events.target_title: Make atk.pc require glib

note.body:
Yes, Samuel's patch works for us.

> But also, @hedning, if we merge it on master during these days, right now my plan is include this on atk 2.35.2, so next stable release with this patch is 2.36.0. But if you need that, I could roll a 2.34.2 release with the patch.

We've added a local patch so there's no hurry for our sake. As long as it lands in upstream at some point we're happy :) More traditional distros like fedora doesn't seem to be hit by this due to global lib and include dirs I'm guessing. So up to you tbh.

events.target_title: g-s/master doesn't always allow moving windows to other workspaces or crashes while moving windows to workspaces [regression compared to 3.32]

note.body:
Looks like `WorkspaceTracker` still assumes workspaces never are reordered (it also doesn't update on `workspaces-reordered`):

https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/blob/085531b43d1a9647af03f9c5d2fa16c6344d63e5/js/ui/windowManager.js#L343-345

`WorkspaceTracker._checkWorkspaces` then operates with the incorrect index -> workspace map, resulting in the wrong workspaces being removed.

Tested this quickly by forcing the correct `WorkspaceTracker._workspaces` array by monkeypatching `_checkWorkspaces`, which fixed the issue.

events.target_title: Add action & info bar

note.body:
Hi all. It may be derailed from the flow of comments, but I would like to share my humble ideas/opinion of actionbar and hope this will help something. Sorry for the distracted bullet points. Here is a quick mockup:

![image](/uploads/4637b7342ecdbb3a65255b342f4fddad/image.png)

- Horizontal spaces should be saved as much as possible, so buttons should be icon style except for remarkable buttons (e.g. "Open" button and "Paste" button).
- "Open" button has an application icon with "Open" label. The button also has a tooltip written "Open with *APP_NAME*".
- Other icon buttons also should have tooltips for beginners (to know what they do).
- "Star" button and "Bookmark" button should be in the same position.
- (If actionbar is one-file-selected mode,) "Cut" and "Copy" buttons may be able to be stored in the hamburger menu since most users would not use the buttons so much, I guess.
- (If actionbar is nothing-selected mode,) "Select All" and "New Folder..." buttons also should be able to be stored in the hamburger menu for the same reason.
- The original idea of "Open with" popup button looks very nice to me. I personally hope it will be realized. :)

events.target_title: Add action & info bar

note.body:
Thanks @csoriano!

I also made an additional mockup of multi items selected actionbar:

![image](/uploads/1769118648cfd6da624b360c12e508bd/image.png)

> How do you imagine that same mockup for a wide Nautilus window i.e. when maximized? Wouldn't it have too much empty space on the middle and the buttons too away?

I personally think it doesn't matter so much, because:

- Most GNOME apps also have much empty spaces in the headerbar and actionbar, but it hasn't become a problem.
- In my mockup, the file name is quite short, but for long file names, wide space would be helpful.
- For high resolution display (e.g. 1920x1080) users, I think it's rare to use Nautilus in the maximized (or wide) window.

> How do you clear the selection? In the previous prototypes we had a "close" button next by the information

I imagined that "single-click to select, double-click or "Open" button to open, single-click again (the selected item) or "Unselect All" menu-button (for multi items selected actionbar) to unselect". But I'm not against the "close" button next by the information if my thought is not enough.

> Why is the bookmark and star icon flat?

It's just to avoid looking heavy. In the Nautilus window, there is already a sidebar on the left. So left is flat, right is raised in my mockup.

> What makes you think cut and copy aren't used as much? It's an interesting question, designers tend to agree with you, however my experience with users is the opposite, seems users perform more actions than just moving around in Nautilus, I would adventure to say it's a 50/50 case.

I imagined that most users would use keyboard shortcuts or context menu instead of actionbar buttons, especially when just one item is selected. In my idea, only when multiple items are selected, "Cut" and "Copy" buttons appear in the actionbar.

> If cut and copy are not as relevant for selection, why paste action received a privileged position in the action bar?

It's to easily know whether or not your clipboard can be pasted in the current directory. In comparison, IMHO it's not very important to know whether items can be copied or cut.

events.target_title: Add action & info bar

note.body:
Hello,

First of all, thanks all for your efforts. Today I tested the new UI with Flatpak so I'd love to share my feedback. (Sorry for the late feedback.)

1. Why will the new Nautilus have *Preferences*, *Help* and *About* items in the Header Bar Menu? According to the [GNOME HIG](https://developer.gnome.org/hig/stable/patterns.html.en), they should be placed in the [Application Menu](https://developer.gnome.org/hig/stable/application-menus.html.en).

2. *New Window* and *New Tab* items also could/should be placed in the location menu.

3. The new search bar (replace the path bar) looks quite different from the [GNOME HIG (Search)](https://developer.gnome.org/hig/stable/search.html.en). I think the inconsistent UI/UX (with other GNOME 3 apps) may confuse users. I personally much prefer the old (current stable) search bar style, because not only it follows the HIG, but also it's **easy to focus on the search window**. The red lines in the screenshot show how to focus on:

![image](/uploads/1671a7d7190f95a88a8cc71f320c3d48/image.png)

So, to summarize my opinions, it'll be like the mockup below:

![image](/uploads/f66a56c68a1cbcd27f9ffcfa75a951db/image.png)

events.target_title: Add action & info bar
Add action & info bar

note.body:
Thanks @csoriano.

> regarding the search bar, this pattern is also used in Web

Do you mean Web is Epiphany? Sorry if I'm something wrong, but as far as I know, even in Epiphany, its search bar (for the contents of the current page, not for web search) appears independently (search bar != location bar).

![image](/uploads/aabf7b1ba1434acbad03ea3aef4c486a/image.png)

As a side note, all major web browsers also don't replace the location bar with a search bar (for the contents search). Most file managers too. Usability-wise, I think it is important for users to focus on the contents page.

> ... and the file chooser.

I understand what you mean (it replaces path bar/location bar), but personally it doesn't bother me because it appears beneath the header bar, not in the header bar. It doesn't conflict with the standard pattern of the GNOME HIG, I guess.

> While I understand the point of being closely attached to the tab,

Yes, and the *sidebar* is also one of the reasons. In 3.28, search bar and content view are seamless and aligned, but in Devel, they are separated and *not aligned*.

> in your proposal for the pathbar menu popover, how would you activate it? Will it allow for navigation clicking the buttons?

Yes, it will. Sorry, my mockup was just poor. 
I was also thinking to display a similar popover by right-clicking on the unchecked buttons (Not sure it is good UI/UX though):

![image](/uploads/8ede2ef0e13451f266db19d575538d50/image.png)

events.target_title: Add action & info bar

note.body:
@csoriano

> Oh I see what you mean. I refer to searching in the web, which is similar to what we do in nautilus since we search on the whole filesystem, not only on the contents displayed in the view.

> The search of nautilus is more close to what the web browsers do for their search/location entries than what the in-page search do.

I see. I was actually thinking the opposite of what you said since Nautilus usually only searches for the current dir (and child dirs), and never searches for the parent or root dirs (unless we are in `/`). So I thought that Nautilus' in-folder entry and Web's in-page entry are similar.

> Right, but as I mentioned this is true for quite a few more things, like sorting, zoom, view menu, the location bar, etc.

Yes, but I just thought the search bar is quite special even compared with other parts, especially for consistency with other GNOME apps.

Anyway I agree to leave this to @aday (and others). I just expressed my opinion as feedback. :)

> Oh I see. So that would require right click right? I was trying to avoid that, and allow interaction only with the left click/taping. You can see how in the current implementation the menu is for the current location only, already selected, so left click works.

I expected that would be useful for (advanced) desktop/laptop users. But right click is required only for the **non-**current location buttons. In the current location button, even in my idea left click/taping is used to open the menu.

Or, for consistent behavior, it might be better to open the menu of all location buttons only with right click/long tap.

note.body: It looks like this will treat an AF_UNIX sockaddr as an AF_INET6 sockaddr, blatting a port number over the start of sun_path.

events.target_title: WIP: Allow http over unix socket

note.body:
For AF_INET sockets, PROP_NAME is treated as a DNS host name.  SET_DATA will be writing to sockaddr_in.sin_addr, which is 32 bits, so this will overflow for any host name longer than four bytes.

Similar for AF_INET6 sockets, but for DNS names longer than 16 bytes.

events.target_title: Expose 'detailed_type' as column to choose...

note.body:
Hello @antoniof 

When using nautilus the 'Type' column is very global. For instance LibreOffice and PDF files are all 'Document's. MOV or AVI are all 'Video's...
I do not like that much. I line more differentiated groups...
I noticed that there is more detail on the 'Properties' page of the file and after looking into the code I realized how easy would be the expose that info as column. And that what I did. Added 'details_type' the the columns to choose...

---

As for the way I posted my code...
Originally forked the GNOME/nautilus project on GitHub, than made my changes and created a pull-request.
Received an email that I should go the GNOME Newcomers wiki and read there how to post my code via Bugzilla...
When proceeding with that Bugzilla redirected me to GitLab to open an issue, and the only way I found to post my code was attaching the patch file I was creating as an earlier step...

Obviously that's not the way yoy expected :-). There is a documentation I can follow in the future?

Regards
Peter

events.target_title: Expose 'detailed_type' as column to choose...

note.body:
@antoniof 
I'm aware of "MIME Type", but it is the other end - too much (and I'm aware that it may sound niggling...)
Let show you in more details...

**For PDF**
Type = Document / 
MIME Type = application/pdf / 
Properties (Ctrl+I) = PDF document (application/pdf)

**For Word Document**
Type = Document / 
MIME Type = application/vnd.openxmlformats-officedocument.wordprocessingml.document / 
Properties (Ctrl+I) = Microsoft Word Document (application/vnd.openxmlformats-officedocument.wordprocessingml.document)

**For LibreOffice Document**
Type = Document / 
MIME Type = application/vnd.oasis.opendocument.text / 
Properties (Ctrl+I) = OpenDocument Text (application/vnd.oasis.opendocument.text)

I liked more the first part of what I saw in Properties window and after investigating the code I found that it is actually made from two attributes (detailed type and mime type) and found also that by adding two simple lines to the code I can expose the detailed type as column to choose...!

[simple](/uploads/2572a083d00fa582a995cf6ac24f2509/simple.png)

Hi @AlexFazakas and @ernestask,

I think the fact that different MIME types have the same Detailed type is perfectly all right - at least from my point of view as user...
It only tells one thing - you can not replace MIME type with Detailed type...
The good thing about Detailed type is that it adds a 3rd level in between the Type and MIME type (too little and too much)... It is also only about exposing Detailed type as column! Nautilus already has that data and used in the CTRL+I (properties) popup...

events.target_title: Metaprojects with subprojects

note.body:
Is this about having multiple source trees open at once and navigating between them? So for example if you hack on Builder you often also dive into libdazzle or even gtk and you want/need to change the code of either "project"?

If so, that's definitively a highly desirable feature. Eclipse calls these things "workspaces". A workspace is basically a set of projects, all configuration in Eclipse is per workspace (which is mostly annoying for me) and the user can configure the "dependencies" for each "project" (e.g. used to include types from dependent projects in the code completion).

With git I often have several smaller components but they are really developed in lock-step (e.g. a front-end service and some back-end/admin interfaces).

events.target_title: Crash unmanaging windows on secondary monitor when “workspaces-only-on-primary”
Crash unmanaging windows on secondary monitor when “workspaces-only-on-primary”

note.body:
When a workspace is set, on_all_workspace should be FALSE. Similarly,
when on_all_workspace is TRUE, the window workspace should be NULL.

This is an assumption in multiple places in the code, including when
setting the workspace state, the window is either added or removed from
all workspaces only if the window's workspace is NULL.

This rule is initially enforced at creation in _meta_window_shared_new()
when a initial workspace is set. However, when the initial workspace is
set from the session info, the initial workspace is not marked as “set”
which leads to assertion failure when unmanaging windows, as the window
is not removed from all the workspaces.

When applying session info to a window, mark the workspace as “set”.

[0001-x11-window-Mark-restored-workspace-as-set.patch](/uploads/b6d5f2ee688175a629209f0eff5db8c2/0001-x11-window-Mark-restored-workspace-as-set.patch)

note.body:
> Possible fix, simple path replacement.

That won't work at all. Why did you changed all the interface names?

> I'm still not sure this is needed, the spec isn't very clear to me.

@mschraal The spec is rather vague in a lot of areas but it's pretty clear here what the track and playlist object paths shouldn't be. As the spec plainly says they can't start with /org/mpris. As far as what they should be, it's a DBus object path (one that doesn't actually lead to anything) I'd shadow your DBus path (not your mpris object path) that's why I suggested /org/gnome/GnomeMusic/TrackList/. The last bit (the part after TrackList/ must be unique though to the point that even if 2 songs are repeated in a tracklist they have diffrent Id's. Other than that it doesn't matter what the Id bit is as long as it's a valid path and you can link a song back to that Id. That's how a client/widget tells you what to play. It basically says here play /org/gnome/GnomeMusic/TrackList/123.

 > And I see different players do different things.

Don't do what everyone else is doing. Trust me when I say that 99.9% of implementations are broken in at least some small way if not barely serviceable. I say that as the maintainer of https://github.com/JasonLG1979/gnome-shell-extensions-mediaplayer and the author of the only actually fully working complete player side implementation in Pithos.

Take the time to read the spec completely a few times.   

> Is there anything like a reference implementation for mpris2 around?

Yep. I wrote them both. My extension is the only client/applet that I'm aware of that implements all of the interfaces. And Pithos is the only player that I'm aware of the that implements all of the interfaces, and they all actually work.

note.body:
As long as ``"/org/gnome/GnomeMusic/Tracklist/{}".format(media.get_id())`` produces a valid DBus object path as per https://dbus.freedesktop.org/doc/dbus-specification.html#message-protocol-names.

In this case as long as ``media.get_id()``  "only contain(s) the ASCII characters "[A-Z][a-z][0-9]_""

events.target_title: Music is not MPRIS spec compliant

note.body:
Its been a while since I used GNOME Music but like I said before if there are situations where a song appears, or can appear more than once in a tracklist it must have a unique Id for each occurrence. It doesn't appear (from the name at least) that ``media.get_id()`` refers to that particular occurrence of the track in the tracklist but would return the same thing for multiple occurrences of the same track in tracklist. If that is the case how is the client to know which occurrence is actually playing? In my extension tracklists/playlists with duplicate Id's are rejected as a whole for that reason, it's a violation of the spec.

For example:

Bad tracklist -

track 1 /org/gnome/GnomeMusic/Tracklist/123

track 2 /org/gnome/GnomeMusic/Tracklist/124

track 1(dup) /org/gnome/GnomeMusic/Tracklist/123

If either track 1 or track 1(dup) is played there is no way to know where we are actually at in the tracklist.

events.target_title: Music is not MPRIS spec compliant
Music is not MPRIS spec compliant

note.body:
> No it won't be unique as it currently is.
>
> The Music playlist is currently always kept in a treemodel, we could maybe just use the index of the model instead. I'd have to check how this impacts other parts of the code.

So this then:

 ```python
def track_to_id(track, index):
    return '/org/gnome/GnomeMusic/Tracklist/{}_{}'.format(track.get_id(), index)
```

The index the track would be fine. It shouldn't effect any other part of the code. MPRIS is the only thing that needs to care about it's own trackId's.

> Another problem with our current media_id approach is that its return value can actually contain invalid characters for an object path, depending on the Grilo plugin used.

We had a similar problem in Pithos. Our trackId's start as Pandora trackTokens which can also contain invalid characters. We just hex encode the trackToken that way it never has invalid characters.

note.body:
> No, that's not correct. Unless you select a specific window, _all_ the app's windows are raised.

I'm sorry that's just not true, you are mistaken.

Your Mpris implementation calls shell_app_activate. 

shell_app_activate returns shell_app_activate_full (app, -1, 0); which if the app is running (and players in media notifications are running) calls shell_app_activate_window (app, NULL, timestamp); Which since the window is null the window with the most recent user time for the app will be raised. Which like I said may not necessarily be the window associated with the media notification that you clicked on.

events.target_title: Launch applications (executable files) by double-clicking
Launch applications (executable files) by double-clicking

note.body:
Well, here are three user stories that come to mind immediately:
* I as a user (e.g., student using an university lab machine) want to launch an application (ELF executable) from $HOME. I am not a system administrator on the machine and don't have root rights, hence I cannot install software using GNOME Software
* I as a user want to launch an application (ELF executable) stored on a USB thumb drive. So far, I was able to just double-click it
* I as a user want to run bash and other scripts that have the executable bit set by just double-clicking them in the file manager, as is possible with just about any other file manager out there. Having to run them from a command line is more cumbersome

events.target_title: Launch applications (executable files) by double-clicking
Launch applications (executable files) by double-clicking

note.body:
The commit message in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/nautilus/commit/3a22ed5b8e3bbc1c59ff3069ee79755168754916 leaves many questions open:

> For long we used to support that since the desktop was part of Nautilus.

So apparently "the desktop" is no longer a part of Nautilus. Which part of GNOME stack is handling "the desktop" now, and will that part of the stack gain the ability to launch executables by double-clicking them? (That was my understanding when I initially heard about these plans - that this functionality would simply be moved to another element in the stack, but wouldn't be removed altogether.)

> Also, back then we didn't have a Software app where you are expected to
installs apps. Back then it was common for apps to be delivered in
a tarball, nowadays that's out of question.

Today we have e.g., Electron apps in zip files, AppImages, etc. and an increasing trend to get applications from the original application authors (e.g, Cura directly from https://ultimaker.com/en/products/ultimaker-cura-software rather than from the distribution or from a software center built into the distribution).

> Now that the desktop is long gone

What is this statement supposed to mean? I think GNOME **is** a desktop environment? Or is the secret plan now to quietly turn it into an interface for controlling mobile phones, power stations, or submarines?

> launching binaries and desktop files from within Nautilus is not as useful

Says who? I beg to differ.
Many people like to launch applications from the desktop (e.g., through desktop files or straight by double clicking the executables).

> Not only that, but we are moving towards a more sandboxed system, and we should use the standard and system wide support for launching apps based on users choices.

Now this sounds to me like an active attempt at making it artificially hard to side-load applications from third parties without having to go through the distribution, its software center, package manager, or Flatpak. What does the "we" stand for? Red Hat? Flatpak? Certainly not users nor third-party application developers...

> We also are not able to be secure enough to handle this

Handle what? The launching of executable applications that are already on the system and can readily be launched e.g., from the command line? This is entirely confusing *making things secure* with *making things cumbersome*.

> we allowed untrusted binaries to be launched

Who decides which applications are trusted? The user, by setting the executable bit on them. Once that bit is set, they are trusted.

> We are not being audited (afaik) and we are not in a position that we can let this issues slip.

Audited by whom? Red Hat? For what? 

> With that altogether, this prevents launching binaries or programs from
Nautilus.

Hence, removing one of the key functions of a file manager from the file manager. It's like the Windows Explorer not being able to run .exe files anymore or the Finder not being able to run .app bundles anymore. Regardless of where they came from. Even those that came with the system.

events.target_title: Launch applications (executable files) by double-clicking

note.body:
> I think in the context of Nautilus, the "desktop" being "gone" doesn't mean very much. It just means they removed the functionality where the ~/Desktop folder's contents are shown over the desktop wallpaper.
> 
> In the latest GNOME version, the wallpaper has no files or folders shown on top of it. That's all.

Which part of the desktop handles that now? Or is it now impossible to put files and directories onto the desktop, degrading it to a mere useless wallpaper with no content on it?

events.target_title: Launch applications (executable files) by double-clicking

note.body:
> Thanks for the Firefox Nightly use case. Indeed, it is unfortunate that such a high profile application is still distributed primarily as a tarball

This is not "unfortunate" but in fact really great, since users can always get the latest Firefox (Nightly and Release) directly from the authors, unchanged by the distribution, always in the latest version, on the day it is released, without having to go through the distribution or its tools. As a user, this allows me to download an application once and download the same bits on all distributions I am running such as Fedora, Ubuntu, openSUSE, etc.

In fact, I use 100% of my productivity applications this way (as "portable" applications that I get directly from the author and not through distribution-provided tools, so as to be sure they can run on more than just one distribution).

> which doesn't provide the features and system integration that we, as users of moderns systems, expect from them. More pressure for adopting proper application bundle distribution methods is necessary.

"Proper application bundle distribution methods" as in "let's kill AppImage and force Flatpak upon everyone"? This change gives me the impression that it is squarely aimed at artificially deteriorating the AppImage user experience (download a file, mark it as executable, be done) by making things more complicated than necessary.

If this really was about security, there would be a message informing the user and asking them what to do. But just removing the ability to launch doesn't make it a bit more secure. Just more cumbersome.

events.target_title: general: Don't allow launching binaries or programs in general

note.body:
> Downloaded binaries doens't have the executable bit set, so you needed to know what is that, how to set it, set it, then run.

Exactly. Which is exactly how, as a user, you say that you "trust" an application.

Which is why the whole "security" point is bogus.

events.target_title: Launch applications (executable files) by double-clicking

note.body:
> I know about the executable bit, but that's still in GUI

Point is, with https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/nautilus/commit/3a22ed5b8e3bbc1c59ff3069ee79755168754916 the executable bit won't help anymore -- Nautilus won't launch binaries even their executable bit is set.

Which makes the security argument bogus, because the executable bit doesn't somehow magically set itself - it represents the user's explicit consent in UNIX to treat the file in question as an executable.

If this really was about security, the GUI for setting the executable bit would have been modified, e.g., informing the user what setting the executable bit means.

events.target_title: Launch applications (executable files) by double-clicking

note.body:
@csoriano  

> Remember this is a developer tool, not a user forum. 
> Specially assuming ill mindset comments are not welcome.

The commit breaks key file manager functionality that has been part of file managers of nearly all operating systems and Linux desktops for decades. A video player that cannot play videos is like a file manager that cannot launch executables. If breaking this core functionality does not qualify as a vaild bug then I frankly don't know what does.

I am not asking for end user support. I am asking the developers to fix this issue and restore key file manager functionality back to a working state.

That the commit also happens to break the usability of the AppImage project which I have started and been working on since roughly a decade ago may well be, and I will give you the benefit of doubt, an unintended side effect. Nevertheless, it breaks my use case and hence the use case of my users. Let's work together to find an acceptable solution, I welcome your ideas how to restore the original AppImage user experience despite the commit in question.

@antoniof 

> AppImage _is_ a proper application bundling distribution method, unlike tarballs. (...) You would enjoy the exact same advantages if the authors delivered it as a proper app bundle.

Thanks for the clarification. Agree.

> Please don't assume ill intent where there is none.

I'll try. Apparently @csoriano wasn't even aware of AppImage, how it works, and that you can really just download files, make them executable, and run them without the need to install anything, without the need to be root, without the need to use GNOME software, etc. So yes, let's assume this breakage was unintended. Now he is aware. Let's see what he will do to un-break it.

```
CALSCALE:GREGORIAN

VERSION:2.0

UID:1db068fb55575e13121dd5cb15dfe31db6327fb8
DTSTAMP:20180113T014126Z

DTEND:20180115T190000

SEQUENCE:3
DESCRIPTION:
CREATED:20180113T014141Z
LAST-MODIFIED:20180113T014141Z
END:VEVENT
```

note.body:
I don't think the user would feel encouraged if GTranslator *discouraged* them instead. E.g. ‘This file contains the following error: [ERROR]. The file is going to be broken and shouldn't be used before you fix it. For now, would you like to save the file anyway?’ (Alternatively, an option to view the raw source in process of it being modified could allow for copying it and working around the issue, but that alone likely doesn't justify having the feature.)

But even if GTranslator ultimately won't allow that, it would at least be nice if it gave some pointers on where to find the issue. However, I guess getting that information might be out of scope for this project (given that it's `msgfmt` who's throwing the error)?

events.target_title: Auto-detect -Bsymbolic, fixes configure on macOS
Mac build fails with glib.h static assertion

note.body:
So... the compiler command includes `-arch i386 -arch x86_64` (unless overridden with `ARCHFLAGS`) which causes sub-compilations in both arches. That fails to compile on the i386 side, because the Homebrew-installed glib's installed headers include compile-time generated 64-bit type definitions that fail the assertions on 32-bit. And even if it compiled I don't think it would link because glib is installed 64-bit-only.

This is all being run from `g-ir-scanner`, and the actual command line and options are coming from Python distutils which bases the options on the compile-time configuration of Python... which as of macOS 10.13.3 is dual-arch i386/x86_64.

The actual problem may be that Homebrew's `g-ir-scanner` runs with the system Python instead of a Homebrew-installed Python because it's got a `#!/usr/bin/env python` and Homebrew installs only version-specific python executables (`python2`, `python3`, etc) in its `PATH`.

If I symlink Homebrew's `python2` to `python` and put that ahead in my `PATH`, it compiles as x86_64 only and everything's fine.

So I _think_ this is a packaging problem with `gobject-introspection` on Homebrew.

events.target_title: Mac build fails with glib.h static assertion

note.body:
It seems the homebrew package has gone back and forth, at one point being fixed by using the brew-installed python2 and then being un-fixed back to the system python: https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/pull/12226

Anyway, this is an external packaging issue, so will document on this end and kinda hope that it gets fixed over in homebrew.

events.target_title: Fails to build with musl

note.body:
@chpe a Linux distribution does not force you to use glibc. There are many distributions out there not using glibc (alpine, void to quote the most popular). So the remark

> In general I feel that if they want to be not glibc-compatible, they should bear the cost, not us

Is not acceptable from a GNOME developer. GNOME is already too much systemd centric which makes portability even harder so please use POSIX specific APIs or something that are in glib/gtk. But requiring glibc is a no-go especially for a library that is used in many other places than GNOME.

I have tried building 0.56.0 and it failed. But the patch from @danyspin97 worked fine, so it would be nice to include it. I admit I've not tested git at the moment.

events.target_title: Fails to build with musl

note.body:
> So "glibc defines the linux API" seems more like a personal opinion than a fact. Usually, sticking with standards (POSIX, XPG etc) is best to avoid issues.

Yes unfortunately those days there is a consensus about developers thinking they are right and everybody must follow or die. systemd is the best example in this place, they basically think “we define the standards just follow us” making the ecosystem even more fragmented than before (even though one of the systemd goal was to remove this fragmentation).

glibc is not a standard, it's a C library - that is much more than C library those days but that's off-topic - there is no reasons to write a software that requires glibc specific extensions when you can avoid them. Using Linux does not require you to use GCC, glibc or even coreutils. Most Gtk libraries and programs are already portable and building fine on other systems than Linux and other libc than glibc (including musl). There is no reasons to make vte - a simple widget library - requiring non-POSIX GNU specific extensions.

Thanks for your quick reply !

If I can give my opinion, yes you should indicate it (I looked for that info before posting an issue here, and wouldn't have posted if I had found it) so we can at least understand what we see.

Anyway, I know you had debates between devs/users about the subject, personally I don't understand that it's not possible anymore to choose the sort key of search results. I can understand that it is not the default behavior, but in my opinion it should be an option as it seems useful for many usages.

I find it sad to have to look for an alternative just for a feature like this one, especially as besides I like using Nautilus.

events.target_title: Exempt nick names from spell checking

note.body:
Hey I would like to contribute to fixing this bug. So I looked up on the GSpell API and this is how I think I should approach the problem: The function - `add_word_to_session(word, word_length)` adds a word to the session dictionary. Using the above function I will add the active room's users to the dictionary. And then call - `clear_session()` whenever the active room's users change and update the users. Any review is much appreciated.
Thanks a ton :smiley:

events.target_title: TopIcon Plus makes GS consume 40-50% cpu time

note.body:
Hi guys,

Not sure if this is helpful with diagnosing and fixing the issue, but here's how I was able to make the CPU usage drop on my computer while using TopIcons Plus:
1. Enable the extension
1. See the CPU go up
1. Change the alignment of the icons (e.g. if it's centered, change to align to the left). At this point the CPU usage goes down dramatically, to normal levels
1. Disable the extension
1. Re-enable it
1. See the CPU go up again - even though the alignment now is different from the initial one
1. Change back to the original alignment
1. See the CPU usage drop back to normal levels

Cheers,
Diogo

events.target_title: [Probably a duplicate but still not fixed since 3.22] Systematic segmentation fault

note.body: Yes

events.target_title: [Probably a duplicate but still not fixed since 3.22] Systematic segmentation fault

note.body:
I admit i don't have this bug on my other computers, even the one with Debian 9.

However i know i'm not entirely alone: Last year i remember there was a bug about that on bugzilla, and google can find this kind of things https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=837146

events.target_title: Fixing Issue #92
Fixing Issue #92

note.body:
Due to my changes the *photos_delete_notification_dispose* will be called **twice**. I think only deleting the files should have its own function without calling the *destroyer*.

Any thoughts?

events.target_title: File opened from "Recent" is Read-Only

note.body:
`        location = l->data;
        printf("HIHIHIHIHIHIHI %s\n", location->uri);

Separate workspaces on multiple monitors
Separate workspaces on multiple monitors

note.body:
Anyway, there it goes:

I'd like to have the workspaces feature work with multiple monitors so that I can have multiple workspaces open at a time and manage them individually. The currently available options do not fit my needs:

 - One big workspace on all monitors at once. The workspace spans the whole displayable area.
 - Only workspaces on the primary monitor, and don't affect any windows on any secondary screens.

Both options kind of work with a bit of setup. The problem is: I find myself often switching between using my laptop only and plugging it into a monitor, so this is not a real option for me.

My proposal is:

Each monitor can display its own workspace independently from the others. The switch workspace shortcuts only applies to one workspace at a time (the one having the mouse in it or the focus for example). When switching to a workspace that is already shown on another screen, both screens essentially "swap" workspaces. This allows for fast transfer of windows across monitors.

events.target_title: Massive slowdown with Rust implementation
Horrendous Rust code organization

note.body:
>  Librsvg's dependencies were in a state of flux, e.g. cairo-rs.  I had to implement some missing APIs there in order to use the Cairo features I needed.

Which is why you don't use those dependencies for production quality code.

> I was learning Rust and Cargo as I did the port.

You don't use that for the same reason.

> I am closing this bug because I don't appreciate people lecturing me on what I should have done in retrospect for nearly a year of work.

If you don't want to do things properly that's up to you, but it seems to me 2.41.x has not been really tested. Arch Linux at least didn't upgrade to 2.41.x until just a month ago, and with this comment:

> 2.40 is EOL, switch to 2.41 again and hope it works this time 

https://git.archlinux.org/svntogit/packages.git/commit/trunk?h=packages/librsvg&id=f584f86cc8ba307596f8e812fec0d77de723053f

The words "hope it works" should not be used when upgrading an important package.

To me it looks like people are starting to find tons of issues, and there will probably be more as more people upgrade.

Not having a revision history that can be properly tested is **BAD**. It's possible to have an alternative branch where a cleaned up history is available, so people can at least build and test past commits. This branch can eventually be merged to master without making any changes to master, and that way, the good history remains.

I already started this work, and I might finish it up if people are interested in testing past commits.

There are many options available, but to me hoping the master branch just magically works is not one of them.

If the issues aren't fixed it might be time for a fork. Switching to the fancy language of the week without backup is never a good idea.

Hi @csoriano-admin-account,

Constructive criticism is defined as:

> Constructive criticism aims to show that an intent or purpose of something is better served by an alternative approach.

If the librsvg project followed my recommendation, the project would be better served. That's the definition of constructive criticism.

librsvg might not want to do what is best for the project, but that doesn't mean my criticism wasn't constructive.

> doesn't help the project nor their developers.

Yes, it does. At least it would, if they were open to criticism.

> Remember we have a high bar expectation for how communication happen in all instances of our community.

But you see, not all the people in the world care about "your community". I care that librsvg works correctly, that's it, not the GNOME community. GNOME developers have made it clear that they are not interested in my needs.

Your "high bar expectations" are actually bad for your community, but you'll never accept that.

Once again I have been bitten by GNOME bad practices, even if I'm not using GNOME. I hoped that maybe librsvg was interested in being a stable library, but apparently that's not the case.

> So please use a more constructive language and split this issue in small, focused and actionable tasks.

It doesn't matter what language I use, the GNOME developers have shown time and again that they have no problem in breaking user experience, and they have shown they are not interested in taking the steps necessary to prevent that.

> Bear in mind this for https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/librsvg/issues/188 and future issues too, please.

Add builtin PDF support
Close window inconsistently saves session state

note.body:
I agree with @mcatanzaro , when you close a tab it only closes Ephy for good if that was the last tab. This is "accidental" since what you were doing was to close the tab. Hence, you were not intending to save that tab in the session state.

That's different than closing the whole Ephy instance. In that case, you would like the whole state to be saved. Arguably, it would be good to have a setting so this would be the default *but optional* behavior.

Thank you. Using:

`/usr/lib/gvfsd-archive file=%u`

Works, but throws this warning various times:

`FIXME: follow symlinks`

And about:

`gio mount archive:[LOCATION]`

I have been unable to figure out what shall go in [LOCATION] for a file in:

`~/Downloads/File.zip`

events.target_title: Volume doesn’t implement mount

note.body: Then would it be safe to use "gvfsd-archive"? Or is it going to be deprecated too?

events.target_title: Volume doesn’t implement mount

note.body:
I understand. Anyway the man page of Gio doesn't provide a clue about how the file URL shall be formatted, and in fact passing "%u" isn't working for me at all with any of the possibilities I have tested.

Furthermore doing:
Exec=/usr/lib/gvfsd-archive file=[FILE]

Does mount [FILE], but:
Exec=/usr/lib/gvfsd-archive file=%u

Does nothing on my system. But the package maintainer says it works for him.

My desktop environment is Deepin, perhaps also a bug there?

events.target_title: Memory leak

note.body:
Well, the fact that this issue is so widespread seems to indicate a fundamental flaw in either the API, the language or the tooling involved. It shouldn't be so easy to create such leaks that, realistically, they will never all be fixed. Playing whack-a-mole with memory leaks fixes the short-term problem, but it is not a solution.

So, investing in better API/languages/tooling to help with the situation would be an actionable item to attack the general problem.

events.target_title: Memory leak

note.body:
Sure, it's not a magic wand -- but I also am not aware of any Rust project that had to basically give up on memory leaks the way Gnome seems to do. Same from my experience with Qt/KDE, btw -- I do not remember big problems with leaks. I would rephrase the posts made above as "memory leaks are just a fact of life that we cannot reliably do something about" -- which is just really sad (understandable, but sad) to see when it comes to technology where in principle, we *could* do something.

That said, I am by far not familiar enough with Vala/the Gnome ecosystem to even remotely understand why that is such a big issue here (not just in gnome shell, also in other GTK based applications I am using).  I am just observing this as an outsider.  I hear it is a lot about refcount cycles (but may have misunderstood). Both Rust and Qt usually do no refcounting and deallocate based on a unique owner (determined statically for Rust, dynamically for Qt), that may be a reason for not having so many leak problems. Or maybe not.

events.target_title: Adjust default window to maximize if screen is smaller or equal to 800px width, and to 950x550 otherwise. Closes: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-tweaks/issues/91

note.body:
The problem is that one size for all small screens and another for big screen won't look good on all of them. For example we can set screens smaller than 1600 to use a window of 1200, but if your screen was 1366, 1200 would be so huge, and if your screen was smaller than 1200, the window would go outside screen (bigger than the visible). Same is true for sizes bigger than 1600, which is why I used division because it guarantees responsiveness.

Are there any specific sizes that you would suggest?

events.target_title: Clutter's master clock is erratic
Clutter's master clock is erratic

note.body:
In case it's not completely obvious, the problem is with cur_tick's interval not staying steady like your monitor's refresh rate does. Animations need to be timed according to the interval/period of the target hardware to appear most smooth.

Even if the known frame interval is slightly wrong (ie. my display is really 16680μs), that's not so important. What's important is staying steady during all animations. So this bug really is not the issue described in https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=781296 but is about numerical stability, leading to visual stability.

Being out of phase is also unimportant. That doesn't affect smoothness, only latency within the range of [0,frame interval).

```ruby
gitlab_pages['artifacts_server_url'] = 'http://localhost:8080/api/v4'
```

I think I know what you’re thinking, that these symbols are just decoration that don’t belong in a font, just like the Web used to have an infatuation with icon fonts that nowadays has been replaced with proper SVG icons. Or when they added icons from Adwaita’s symbolic theme (like the keyboard) to overcome silly technical limitations in GNOME Shell.

But I think this isn’t the case here. As it was argued when these symbols were added to Unicode, I can foresee them being utilized in e.g., manuals (especially now that Cantarell is print-quality!). There are use cases beyond the example I gave, the GtkSwitch widget.

Object Shell.GenericContainer has been already finalized. Impossible to get any property from it.

note.body:
@3v1n0 I may have a simpler fix to ui/tweener.js in !11

I've been looking at the "has already been finalized" errors that occur when changing the desktop background. This is one of several cases where there the target is destroyed in the onComplete function passed to addTween().

From looking at it the errors are arising because ui/tweener.js adds it's own onComplete handler that calls _resetTweenState(), this then tries to read the __ShellTweenerState property from the target. This is being executed after the onComplete passed to addTween(), so where the addTween() callers onComplete destroys the target and so the target has already been finalised when _resetTweenState() tries to read the property.

My change just reverses the exectution order of the onComplete handlers so that _resetTweenState() is executed before the target is destroyed.

I've tested for the changing the desktop background scenario and this resolves the errors. Should equally apply to other errors where either of these lines appear in stack trace (of which this issue is one):

resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/tweener.js:73

resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/tweener.js:80

push_data.commit_title: Ensure that _resetTweenState() can be called by _tweenCompleted() b...

events.target_title: Use custom fork of secret-service that removes AVX2 ASM instructions
Fractal executes `xdg-open` on downloaded files when you click on pictures.

note.body:
I think to mitigate damage, it would be good to have an allow list that lists trusted file formats. This could be things like images (.jpg, .png), videos (.mp4, .webm, .mkv) and documents (.pdf, .odt). When a file is on the allow list we can assume that it is safe to just use xdg_open.
When the file is not on the list, in my mind it would be best to simply download the file and let the user decide what to do next.

events.target_title: Fractal executes `xdg-open` on downloaded files when you click on pictures.

note.body: UI wise one could display an icon for each group of files. Images are displayed inline and videos, documents, etc. could all have their own icon to let the user know what it is. When the file is not in the allow list that could also be signalled by another maybe more generic icon.

You can't have it both ways, no.

events.target_title: gdk: do not deactivate surface on keyboard grab

note.body:
Regarding terminology: the X server only has a focus window and a grab window, the keyboard window is always one of those two, depending on the grab state. So you can have FK or GK, but never K != F && K != G. Also, there is no "nothing" in the server, something always has the focus. But for GDK that concept is fine.

I think you have the `NotifyGrab/Ungrab` wrong because I'm not sure whether the ungrab is implied or not (the commit message of 6cc7f060 is a bit ambiguous here too).

Either way: `NotifyGrab` is sent when a grab activates and *both* `FocusIn` and `FocusOut` events have `NotifyGrab`. Likewise for `NotifyUngrab`.

Let's assume your window W has the focus, we have these cases:

The case of your window grabbing the keyboard:
* W grabs the keyboard: W gets `FocusOut(NotifyGrab)` followed by `FocusIn(NotifyGrab)`.
* W ungrabs the keyboard: W gets `FocusOut(NotifyUngrab)` followed by `FocusIn(NotifyUngrab)`

From W's point-of-view, the `FocusOut(NotifyGrab)` means you still have the focus and get it back at some point.

The case of another window W2 grabbing the keyboard:
* W2 grabs the keyboard: W gets `FocusOut(NotifyGrab)`, W2 gets `FocusIn(NotifyGrab)`.
* W2 ungrabs the keyboard: W2 gets `FocusOut(NotifyUngrab)`, W gets `FocusIn(NotifyGrab)`

This is the same as above, just with W and W2 now. From W's point-of-view, a `FocusOut(NotifyGrab)` means you still have the focus and get it back at some point.

The case of another window W2 grabbing the keyboard **and** then setting the focus to W2:
* W2 grabs the keyboard: W gets `FocusOut(NotifyGrab)`, W2 gets `FocusIn(NotifyGrab)`
* W2 changes the focus to W2: W gets `FocusOut(NotifyWhileGrabbed)`, W2 gets `FocusIn(NotifyWhileGrabbed)`
* W2 ungrabs the keyboard: W gets nothing, W2 gets `FocusOut(NotifyUngrab)` followed by `FocusIn(NotifyGrab)`

From W's point-of-view, a `FocusOut(NotifyWhileGrabbed)` means you've lost the focus now.

@sthibaul comment https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/merge_requests/120#note_104782 is correct though so I think it's just the commit message here that could need expansion.

> "And if the above is indeed correct, then @matthiasc's worries are unfounded because we get indeed notified when the focus changes and windows lose their F status during a grab."

This is correct, you can track the focus changes even while someone else has a grab.

events.target_title: Touchpad and Trackpoint locked together in Wayland session

note.body:
evemu records kernel events directly, independent of the display manager. Likewise `evemu replay` is independent. The `trackpoint_wayland` recording doesn't contain any events but the xorg one does. So replaying either will always produce the same results for that respective file.

the second set of recordings in the comment above also don't have any events. So this indicates that the kernel isn't sending events, because the only other explanation is another client having an `EVIOCGRAB` - but evemu warns about that. So right now it looks more like a kernel issue than a gnome issue.

But it looks like we still don't quite know what the underlying behaviour is. To narrow this down, run evemu-record again in every combination (wayland/xorg touchpad disabled/enabled) and check for any events. Whenever you don't see events from the event node, that's a case to note because this simply shouldn't happen.

There's a remote chance that the i2c bus shuts down/resets when the last client disconnects or something. To avoid this, make sure you start evemu-record while the trackpoint is working, leave it running and *then* disable the trackpoint in GNOME. Does it still work then?

events.target_title: add tap-and-drag option

note.body:
* normal tap: finger down, finger up → equivalent to mouse button press/release
* normal tap: finger down, finger up, finger down and held down → button press/release, then normal movements as the finger moves.

* tap-and-drag: finger down, finger up, finger down and held down → button press but no release. Any movement of the finger now results in a movement as if the button was still held down, only the finger up releases the button.

* tap-and-drag-lock: same as above, but the button release happens after a timeout, allowing a user to reset the finger on the touchpad without losing the drag.

libinput also has some documentation with pretty pictures: https://wayland.freedesktop.org/libinput/doc/latest/tapping.html

The reason for having a tap-and-drag toggle is that some interactions require a "click, move, click, move, click, move" sequence. Think of e.g. ticking multiple checkboxes. With tap-and-drag **on**, this becomes a drag-drag-drag sequence and can make it effectively impossible to interact with the application unless you wait for timeouts after every click. So this is less an accessibility issue and more "I cannot use my touchpad to do this workflow".

The problem with tap-and-drag enabled is that to drag you need to keep holding the finger down. When you drag something across the screen you may hit the touchpad's edge before reaching the target zone on the screen. Then you're stuck - releasing the finger could stop the drag (it's mouse button up). Movign the finger back would drag the content back too. That's what the drag lock does, it allows you to quickly lift the finger, put it down somewhere else and then keep moving into the same direction. Same thing you do when moving across screens, but the drag is being held the whole time.
This is timeout-controlled (lifting the finger long enough releases the drag) and activity-controlled (a tap after a locked drag releases the drag). See the link above.

Defaults in libinput are: tap-and-drag enabled, drag-lock disabled.

I recommend keeping those, drag-lock enabled by default can be quite annoying and results in lots of bug reports.

The relationship is hierarchical: drag-lock is a subfeature of tap-and-drag is a subfeature of tapping. Disabling the higher feature makes the lower feature moot. This means it has to be grouped in the UI unless you just want to automatically disable tap-and-drag whenever tap-to-click is disabled.

Regarding your summary:

> - "Tap to drag" allows lifting the finger off the touchpad while dragging. This can be useful if the touchpad is very small, since it allows repeated drags across the pad.

Just to clarify - this is drag-lock

> - Tap to drag is an alternative to either a) using a physical touchpad button or b) using a push action on the touchpad, if it supports it.

I'm not sure what a push action is, but I think you're correct here. Is a push-action the clickpad "hold the touchpad physically down while moving the finger"? If so, correct.

> - It's a "locking" behaviour - the user taps the object to activate, can then drag as much as they want, then taps again to disengage. In this respect, it conflicts with "tap to click".

as above, I think you're referring to drag-lock here. Tap to disengage is possible but not required, there is always a timeout but it can be 'uncomfortably' long, so a quick tap can be more convenient. See the libinput doc link I posted above.

events.target_title: Add "Disable touchpad while typing" switch

note.body:
yes, it's a software feature, controlled by libinput. We ignore input from the touchpad for $TIMEOUT milliseconds after the last key event, give or take a few extra conditions. See the [libinput documentation](https://wayland.freedesktop.org/libinput/doc/latest/palm_detection.html#disable-while-typing) for some details.

It's enabled by default for all touchpads mostly because it's the only "reliable" palm detection that works on all touchpads. It doesn't depend on touchpad capabilities, unlike e.g. pressure-based palm detection. It may be possible to not use it by default on some touchpads (macs for example) but that requires someone with a mac to care sufficiently to test this. It's not available on external touchpads because it's not needed there.

It's a configuration toggle in libinput because there are some use-cases, notably games but also graphics programs, where the interaction is keys *and* touchpad rather than the usual keys **or** touchpad. DWT gets in the way there and must be disabled, there's no good other workaround here.

events.target_title: Touchpad: Give us an option to disable horizontal scrolling with two fingers under Wayland

note.body: Note that come libinput 1.12 this option may not be needed anymore. We have better scroll locking now and accidental horizontal movements should be significantly reduced.

events.target_title: Motion on tablet tip events is ignored
